parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about technological innovation in education. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: The Digital Classroom Revolution
passage.content:
Dr. Elena Vasquez stood at the front of her classroom at Riverside University, but instead of a traditional whiteboard behind her, a large interactive display showed a three-dimensional model of the human heart. Her students, scattered across different continents, watched from their homes as she manipulated the virtual organ, zooming in to show individual blood vessels.

'This is the future of education,' Elena explained to visiting colleagues later that day. 'We're not just teaching anatomy; we're creating immersive experiences that help students understand complex concepts in ways that textbooks never could.'

The transformation hadn't happened overnight. When Elena first started teaching fifteen years ago, her biggest technological challenge was getting the overhead projector to work properly. Now, her students used virtual reality headsets, artificial intelligence tutoring systems, and collaborative platforms that connected learners from around the world.

The benefits were clear. Student engagement had increased dramatically, and complex subjects that once required extensive memorization could now be explored interactively. 'Students don't just read about molecular structures,' Elena noted. 'They can build them, manipulate them, and see how they react under different conditions.'

However, the transition presented significant challenges. Many older faculty members struggled with the new technology, requiring extensive training and support. The university also had to invest heavily in infrastructure, upgrading internet bandwidth and purchasing expensive equipment.

Perhaps the biggest concern was ensuring that technology enhanced rather than replaced human interaction. 'We have to be careful not to lose the personal connection between teacher and student,' Elena warned. 'Technology should amplify our teaching abilities, not substitute for genuine educational relationships.'

Looking ahead, Elena was optimistic about further developments. Emerging technologies like augmented reality and machine learning promised even more personalized and effective learning experiences. 'We're just at the beginning,' she concluded. 'The next decade will bring innovations we can barely imagine today.'

parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about sustainable living practices. Six paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-G the one which fits each gap (7-12). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: Creating Sustainable Communities
passage.content:
Communities around the world are discovering that small changes in daily habits can lead to significant environmental improvements. These grassroots movements are proving that ordinary citizens can make extraordinary differences.

[7]

One of the most successful approaches has been community gardening initiatives. Neighborhoods are converting unused lots into productive green spaces where residents can grow their own food.

[8]

Waste reduction programs represent another powerful tool for sustainable communities. By implementing comprehensive recycling and composting systems, neighborhoods can dramatically reduce their environmental footprint.

[9]

Energy conservation efforts have also gained momentum in recent years. Communities are organizing bulk purchases of solar panels, sharing the costs and installation expertise among multiple households.

[10]

Transportation initiatives are addressing one of the largest sources of community pollution. Bike-sharing programs, carpooling networks, and improved public transit access are reducing dependence on individual car ownership.

[11]

Education plays a crucial role in sustaining these environmental efforts. Community workshops teach residents practical skills like composting, energy-efficient home improvements, and sustainable cooking methods.

[12]

The success of these community-led initiatives demonstrates that environmental protection doesn't require massive government programs or corporate intervention - it starts with neighbors working together.

paragraphs.text: These gardens not only provide fresh produce but also create social connections and reduce transportation costs associated with food distribution.
Some communities have reduced their waste output by up to 60% through these coordinated efforts, proving that collective action produces measurable results.
The key to successful sustainability programs lies in starting small and gradually expanding initiatives as community support grows.
This collaborative approach makes renewable energy affordable for families who couldn't manage the investment individually.
These educational programs ensure that sustainable practices continue even as community membership changes over time.
Many participants report that these transportation alternatives have improved their health while reducing their environmental impact.
However, maintaining long-term commitment requires ongoing leadership and community engagement from dedicated volunteers.

parts.instructions: You are going to read about four people who have unusual hobbies. For questions 13-22, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Marco Silva - Storm Chaser
people.text: Most people run away from severe weather, but I drive toward it. I've been chasing storms across the Midwest for twelve years, documenting tornadoes and severe thunderstorms for research purposes. The adrenaline rush is incredible, but safety is always my top priority. I use sophisticated weather tracking equipment and maintain constant communication with meteorological services. My photographs and videos have been used by universities and weather services to better understand storm formation. The unpredictable nature of weather means I might drive hundreds of miles and see nothing, or witness a once-in-a-lifetime tornado.

people.name: Lisa Park - Urban Explorer
people.text: I explore abandoned buildings, tunnels, and forgotten spaces in cities around the world. There's something fascinating about places that time has left behind - old factories, unused subway stations, derelict hospitals. I always research the history of these locations before exploring them. Safety equipment is essential because these places can be dangerous. I never damage or remove anything; the motto is 'take only photographs, leave only footprints.' My explorations have led to discovering historical artifacts and documenting architectural heritage that might otherwise be lost forever.

people.name: David Chen - Competitive Yo-Yo Player
people.text: People often laugh when I tell them I'm a professional yo-yo competitor, but it's a legitimate sport with world championships and serious prize money. I practice six hours daily, developing new tricks and perfecting my technique. The physics involved are complex - gyroscopic motion, string tension, and centrifugal force all play crucial roles. I've traveled to competitions in thirty countries and have won several regional titles. The community is surprisingly international and supportive. Modern yo-yos are precision instruments, some costing over $500, made from aluminum and featuring advanced bearing systems.

people.name: Sarah Martinez - Beekeeping Instructor
people.text: I maintain eight beehives in my backyard and teach urban beekeeping classes to city residents. Many people fear bees, but they're gentle creatures when treated with respect. Beekeeping requires patience and observation skills - you learn to read the hive's mood and health through subtle signs. The environmental benefits are significant; my bees pollinate gardens throughout the neighborhood. I harvest about 200 pounds of honey annually and sell it at local farmers' markets. Climate change and pesticides pose serious threats to bee populations, so education about bee conservation is becoming increasingly important.
